topics.body:
"@Number1pegasus":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5595b49d636872618f00011e#post_5595b49d636872618f00011e
The biggest argument I've seen towards cg in anime is that it doesn't make visual sense and clashes with an otherwise traditionally animated format. And because the difference is so jarring it takes you out of the story and destroys your immersion.
topics.author: 4fde4618945b700aa0002fff

topics.body: I do think that Show by rock's CGI bits worked so well because they were used with the Sanrio things.
topics.author: 5062d6f17f123b3e16001184

topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5595b47b636872618f0000f7#post_5595b47b636872618f0000f7
The biggest fuck up when it comes to cgi in anime is that rookies tend to put too much shading into the characters.

A good way to get around the shading problem to make 3d modeled characters unnoticeable is to have a high polygon count 3d character and have the shading difference very subtle.

Tl:dr; very high polygon count 3d models with little light shading = less noticeable cgi.

topics.body:
Apparently a Volkswagon employee in germany was killed by a robot.

Basically what happened was that he was performing maintenance on it and it thought he was a car door and picked him up and slammed him into a metal cage.

And that ladies and gentlemen is why you don't put yourself in front of industrial machinery.
